channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Ukraine Live Updates: 3 European Leaders Head to Kyiv as Attacks Continue
item.description: The leaders of the Czech Republic, Poland and Slovenia planned to express the European Union’s “unequivocal support” for Ukraine. Blasts shook the Ukrainian capital before dawn, and the mayor ordered a citywide curfew.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian firefighters outside of a destroyed apartment building after bombing in Kyiv on Tuesday.

item.title: Impunity for Syria War Crimes Casts Shadow Over Ukraine
item.description: Syria, with Russian support, used many of the brutal tactics now seen in Ukraine — and its dictator stayed in power. That conflict offers lessons for Russia’s leader, analysts say.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Homs, Syria, in 2014. The Syrian war began 11 years ago this month with an anti-Assad uprising that spiraled into a multisided conflict.

item.title: Indian Court Upholds Ban on Hijabs in Schools
item.description: One school’s initial ban set off unrest and violence that spread to other schools in the southern state of Karnataka.
item.dc:creator: Sameer Yasir
item.media:description: Hijab-wearing students arriving for classes, in February as a police officer stood guard outside a government school in the town of Udupi in the southern state of Karnataka, India.

item.title: Cambodian Temple, Once Overcrowded, Wants Tourists Back
item.description: Cambodia has been open to foreign tourists for months, but in this time of Covid, few have made the trip, making it possible to imagine that you alone have rediscovered the glorious temple complex.
item.dc:creator: Richard C. Paddock and Thomas Cristofoletti
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:credit: Thomas Cristofoletti for The New York Times

item.title: China Sees at Least One Winner Emerging From Ukraine War: China
item.description: The country’s leaders think it can shield itself from economic and diplomatic fallout and eventually be seen as a pillar of stability.
item.dc:creator: Steven Lee Myers and Chris Buckley
item.media:description: The Great Hall of the People in Beijing. China’s leaders have calculated that they can benefit from geopolitical shifts brought about by the war in Ukraine.

item.title: Turkmenistan Leader’s Son Wins Presidential Election
item.description: The oil-rich country’s dealings are largely opaque, but its central election commission said Serdar Berdymukhammedov had captured nearly 73 percent of the vote.
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.media:description: Serdar Berdymukhammedov, the son of Turkmenistan’s leader, in 2021.

item.title: Two Refugees, Both on Poland’s Border. But Worlds Apart.
item.description: A young man fleeing war in Sudan and a young woman evacuating Ukraine crossed into Poland at the same time. They had very different experiences.
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Gettleman and Monika Pronczuk
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.media:description: Concertina wire separating the borders of Poland and Belarus at the closed border crossing point in Kuznica, Poland, on Thursday.

item.title: Wave of Omicron Infections Prompts Lockdowns in China
item.description: After two years of largely containing coronavirus outbreaks, China’s “Covid zero” policies are being tested by the highly transmissible variant.
item.dc:creator: Keith Bradsher
item.media:description: Police and workers at an area under lockdown in Shanghai on Monday.

item.title: The Latest Covid Surge
item.description: A new version of Omicron and Hong Kong’s rising death toll.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:description: Medical workers from China arriving yesterday at the Hong Kong border.

item.title: Inside the High-Stakes Race to Test the Covid Tests
item.description: Researchers in Atlanta have helped the federal government evaluate dozens of Covid tests and pioneer a new model for developing novel diagnostics.
item.dc:creator: Emily Anthes
item.media:credit: Johnathon Kelso for The New York Times

item.title: In Africa, a Mix of Shots Drives an Uncertain Covid Vaccination Push
item.description: Supplies are more plentiful now but they are unpredictable and often a jumble of brands. Many places can’t meet the W.H.O.’s recommended dosing schedules.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Nolen and Rebecca Robbins
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: Abdul K. Bangura, a health worker in Sierra Leone, delivering a cooler of Covid vaccine doses to the village of Kathantha Yimbo, about 40 miles from Kamakwie, last month.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: Attacks on Kyiv.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Residents of a shelled building in Kyiv, Ukraine, mourned their losses on Monday as Russian forces kept bombarding the city.

item.title: Zelensky Calls on Russian Troops to Surrender
item.description: The Ukrainian leader and the Pentagon have both said some Russian soldiers have surrendered or been captured.
item.dc:creator: Jesus Jiménez
item.media:description: A Russian armored vehicle destroyed by Ukrainian forces near Mykolaiv earlier this month.

item.title: Diplomacy Quickens to Halt Ukraine War or Stop Its Expansion
item.description: Ukraine and Russia held a new round of talks and agreed to resume them on Tuesday, as the United States warned China about helping an increasingly isolated Kremlin and expanding the conflict.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler and David E. Sanger
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: An apartment complex damaged by shelling on Monday morning in the Obolon district in Kyiv, Ukraine.

item.title: Kyiv’s Once-Busy Streets Empty as Russia Targets Capital
item.description: With civilian areas coming under fire and an estimated half the population having fled, the avenues of the Ukrainian capital, under siege by Russian forces, are almost deserted.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Residents salvaged what belongings they could after a residential building in Kyiv was shelled on Monday.

item.title: He’s American, He Oversees Papa John’s in Russia and He’s Staying
item.description: Christopher Wynne’s company controls the franchise agreements for the 190 Papa John’s locations in the country. “At the end of the day, they appreciate a good pizza,” he said.
item.dc:creator: Julie Creswell
item.media:description: Christopher Wynne in 2017. He moved to Russia in the early 2000s and got involved with Papa John’s there in 2007.

item.title: Anti-War Protester Storms a Live Broadcast on Russia’s Most-Watched News Show
item.description: The intervention by a state TV employee underscored how dissent is seeping into the public sphere in Russia, despite the Kremlin’s crackdown on anyone who challenges its official narrative of the invasion.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing: Russia Bombards Kyiv
item.description: Plus China’s effort to contain its biggest coronavirus outbreak since Wuhan.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Residents of the building break down as they try to salvage whatever belongings they can in Kyiv, Ukraine.

item.title: The U.S. Warns China Not to Give Russia Military or Economic Aid
item.description: The Kremlin denied the report, and the spokesman for the Chinese Embassy in Washington said he had never heard of the request.
item.dc:creator: Richard Pérez-Peña and David E. Sanger
item.media:description: The close relationship between the Russian and Chinese presidents prompted American officials to warn China not to assist Russia militarily or economically.

item.title: Three House Democrats Test Positive for Covid After Retreat
item.description: All four House members attributed their lack of severe symptoms to protection from vaccines.
item.dc:creator: Anushka Patil and Annie Karni
item.media:credit: From left: Anna Moneymaker for The New York Times and Stefani Reynolds for The New York Times
item.media:description: From left: Representatives Madeleine Dean, Rosa DeLauro and Zoe Lofgren

item.title: U.K. Supreme Court Says Assange Cannot Appeal His Extradition to U.S.
item.description: In a blow for the embattled WikiLeaks founder, the court said it had refused permission to appeal “because the application does not raise an arguable point of law.”
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.category: Supreme Court of the United Kingdom
item.media:description: Supporters of Julian Assange tied yellow ribbons on the railings of the Royal Courts of Justice in London to show their support for the WikiLeaks founder in October.

item.title: Lithuania, a Vulnerable NATO Link, Readies for Putin and Russia
item.description: The Baltics, wedged between Russia and Belarus, have been likened to a modern-day West Berlin. Many here worry that if Ukraine falls, they might be next.
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Andrea Mantovani for The New York Times
item.media:description: A flag-raising ceremony of the three Baltic States in Independence Square, in Vilnius, Lithuania, last week.

item.title: Britain Announces ‘Homes For Ukraine’ Program to Sponsor Refugees
item.description: The program, called “Homes for Ukraine,” offers a new route for Ukrainian refugees to come to Britain, which had previously been limited to those joining family members already living there.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:credit: Maciek Nabrdalik for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian refugees in Poland on Sunday. Britain has said it will admit refugees who can be matched with sponsors offering them a place to live.

item.title: A Conductor on Why He Stayed in Russia After the Invasion Began
item.description: The Estonian American conductor Paavo Järvi chose to remain in Moscow temporarily to lead a Russian youth orchestra: “I felt a responsibility.”
item.dc:creator: Javier C. Hernández
item.media:credit: Michelle V. Agins/The New York Times
item.media:description: Paavo Järvi conducting in 2019. “I could not turn my back on these young musicians at such a difficult and confusing time,” he recently said.

item.title: Zelensky to Address Congress in Virtual Speech
item.description: The Ukrainian president’s speech will likely increase growing momentum on Capitol Hill to pressure President Biden to send fighter jets to Kyiv.
item.dc:creator: Catie Edmondson
item.media:description: President Volodymyr Zelensky addressed a joint sitting of the Polish parliament in Warsaw last week.

item.title: Hong Kong Lacks the Resources For a China-style Pandemic Resonse, Official Says
item.description: “Hong Kong is very different from many mainland cities and therefore we cannot have any comparison,” Mrs. Lam told reporters at a news conference.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Stevenson
item.media:description: An isolation facility for Covid-19 patients being built in Hong Kong, next to a bridge linking the city with Shenzhen in mainland China, on Friday.

item.title: Woman Photographed After Russian Strike On Maternity Hospital Has Died
item.description: Her baby also died, the news organization said. The photo captured last week has become one of the defining images of human suffering in the war.
item.dc:creator: Austin Ramzy
item.media:description: The woman was injured in a Russian missile strike on a maternity hospital in Mariupol last week.

item.title: New York Times Launches Telegram Channel for Russia-Ukraine War
item.description: The channel delivers reporting from our continuous live blog, where Times journalists are providing witness accounts, interviews and breaking news from the Russia-Ukraine conflict.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: In Brovary, east of Kyiv, smoke rose from a frozen-food warehouse after it was hit by shelling.

item.title: Novel Malaria Treatment for Children Receives First Approval
item.description: The single-dose medication, for treatment of a particular form of malaria, is a new weapon in the war against the deadly illness.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.media:description: A light micrograph of Plasmodium vivax, a parasite that causes malaria, in a section of human liver.

item.title: How President Zelensky Became a National Hero in Ukraine
item.description: We look at Volodymyr Zelensky’s rise.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Volodymyr Zelensky, Ukraine’s president, holding a news conference this month.

item.title: Tree Planting Is Booming. Here’s How That Could Help, or Harm, the Planet.
item.description: Reforestation can fight climate change, uplift communities and restore biodiversity. When done badly, though, it can speed extinctions and make nature less resilient.
item.dc:creator: Catrin Einhorn
item.media:description: The California Conservation Corps planting trees in Modesto, Calif. Researchers say it is increasingly urgent to factor biodiversity into restoration efforts.

item.title: IPhone Manufacturer Foxconn Suspends Production Because of Covid Lockdown
item.description: The Taiwanese electronics firm said it “adjusted the production line” to other plants in China to minimize any impact on operations.
item.dc:creator: Tiffany May
item.media:description: An Apple store in Shenzhen, China, in 2019. Foxconn’s factories in Shenzhen will suspend operations during a seven-day coronavirus lockdown.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing
item.description: A Russian assault on NATO’s doorstep.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times

item.title: Russian Airstrike Near Poland’s Border Fuels NATO’s Fear of Expanded War
item.description: Russian missiles hit a military base being used to train foreign volunteers who want to help Ukraine repel the invasion, killing a reported 35 people just 11 miles from the Polish border.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora, Jack Nicas and Eric Schmitt

item.title: Airstrike Damages Revered Monastery in Ukraine
item.description: The 16th-century monastery is one of the three most sacred sites in Ukraine for Orthodox believers.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:description: The Holy Dormition Svyatogorsk Lavra, a major Orthodox Christian monastery near the town of Svyatogorsk in Donetsk in December.

item.title: Finding a Way Out of the War in Ukraine Proves Elusive
item.description: Attempts at diplomacy have hit a stone wall as President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia refuses to engage in any serious negotiation, but his endgame is unclear.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger and Eric Schmitt
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston for The New York Times
item.media:description: Demonstrators gathered near the White House last month to protest Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.

item.title: ‘The Power of the Dog’ Wins Best Film at Wide-Open BAFTAs
item.description: Jane Campion won the best director prize at Britain’s Academy Awards for her tense western in an evening that saw a host of surprise winners.
item.dc:creator: Alex Marshall
item.category: British Academy of Film and Television
item.media:description: The actor Benedict Cumberbatch (“The Power of the Dog”) on the red carpet at the EE BAFTA Film Awards at the Royal Albert Hall in London.

item.title: Booms, Smoke and Fire Signal Horror of Russian Attack on Base
item.description: Residents of a town near Poland’s border awoke to frightful sounds and an awareness they were no longer safe.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins and Yousur Al-Hlou
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: A soldier hurt in Sunday’s attack at a base close to the Polish border was among the wounded seen outside the nearby Novoyavorivsk District Hospital.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing: Deadly Airstrikes in Ukraine’s West
item.description: Plus Omicron’s impact in the South Pacific and the struggles of the French Greens.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Cullen

item.title: Former President Obama Tests Positive for the Coronavirus
item.description: He tweeted that he has a scratchy throat but is otherwise fine.
item.dc:creator: Traci Carl
item.media:description: Former President Barack Obama speaking at a campaign drive-in rally for Joe Biden in 2020.

item.title: Russia Asked China for Military and Economic Aid for Ukraine War, U.S. Officials Say
item.description: Jake Sullivan, the U.S. national security adviser, plans to meet with a top Chinese official on Monday in Rome to discuss the war and China’s role.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong and Julian E. Barnes

item.title: ‘Things Will Only Get Worse.’ Putin’s War Sends Russians Into Exile.
item.description: Thousands of Russians saw their comfortable, middle-class lives fade overnight with the invasion ordered by President Vladimir V. Putin.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski and Patrick Kingsley
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Russians who fled after Russia invaded Ukraine gathered Saturday at a volunteer’s apartment in Istanbul to share their stories and get tips on settling in Turkey.

item.title: Ukrainian Refugees Find Shelter and a Hearty Welcome For Their Pets in Romania
item.description: Viktor and Rachel Borovic had only two hours to prepare to flee their city. But they were clear about what was important to them.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Cohen
item.media:credit: Cristian Movila for The New York Times
item.media:description: Viktor and Rachel Borovic traveled from Sumy, Ukraine, with their dog, Busia, and their cat, Coco, to a makeshift shelter in the Mandachi Hotel and Spa in Suceava, Romania.

item.title: Power Supply Restored at Nuclear Plant in Chernobyl, Ukraine Says
item.description: Russian troops have occupied the nuclear power plant since late February.
item.dc:creator: Jesus Jiménez
item.media:description: A monument in front of the giant protective dome built over the sarcophagus of the destroyed fourth reactor of Chernobyl nuclear power plant, as seen in a photograph from 2020.

item.title: Biden Administration Fights in Court to Uphold Some Trump-Era Immigration Policies
item.description: Immigration activists and Democrats say there is a disconnect between the president’s words at the lectern and the government’s litigation in the courtroom.
item.dc:creator: Zolan Kanno-Youngs
item.media:credit: Benjamin Lowy for The New York Times
item.media:description: Migrants crossed the Rio Grande between Ciudad Acuña, Mexico, and Del Rio, Texas, in September.

item.title: Filmmaker Brent Renaud Spent His Career Capturing the Human Toll of War
item.description: Mr. Renaud’s final assignment was documenting refugees fleeing across bridges in Irpin, Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Alyssa Lukpat

item.title: Afghan Aviators Hide as Taliban Urge Them to Return to Duty
item.description: Many former Afghan Air Force members fear they could be killed by the Taliban if they came out of hiding, but others have joined the nascent Taliban air force.
item.dc:creator: David Zucchino and Yaqoob Akbary
item.media:credit: Jim Huylebroek for The New York Times
item.media:description: A former member of an elite divison of the Afghan Air Force who refused to join the Taliban’s force is now in hiding in Kabul.

item.title: Unvaccinated M.L.B. Players Will Not Be Allowed to Play in Canada
item.description: Canada’s border restrictions bar those players, and the players will not be paid while the team is abroad as part of the sport’s new labor agreement.
item.dc:creator: James Wagner
item.media:description: At Rogers Centre in Toronto in September.

item.title: Red Cross Warns Time Is Running Out For Civilians in Mariupol
item.description: Russian forces encircled the city nearly two weeks ago, and as the death toll rises, eyewitnesses have reported there is little food or clean water, and no medicine.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora and Nick Cumming-Bruce
item.category: International Committee of the Red Cross
item.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier guards his position on Saturday in Mariupol, Ukraine.

item.title: 300,000 in Hong Kong Isolate at Home as COVID Cases Rise
item.description: The city’s officials are scrambling to build quarantine and mass quarantine centers as cases of the Omicron and Delta variants spread widely.
item.dc:creator: Tiffany May
item.media:description: Health care workers delivering items to patients at a makeshift Covid-19 isolation facility in Hong Kong on Friday.

item.title: Brent Renaud, an American Journalist, Is Killed in Ukraine
item.description: An award-winning filmmaker and journalist, Mr. Renaud, 50, was killed while reporting in a suburb of Kyiv. Another journalist was wounded.
item.dc:creator: Michael Schwirtz
item.media:description: Brent Renaud, right, and his brother Craig in Little Rock, Ark., in 2007.
